title: Balancing the Benefits and Harms of Oral Anticoagulation in Chronic Kidney Disease: What Does Available Evidence Tell Us?
abstract: Editorials6 August 2019Balancing the Benefits and Harms of Oral Anticoagulation in Chronic Kidney Disease: What Does Available Evidence Tell Us?Ainslie Hildebrand, MD, MSc, Christine Ribic, MD, MSc, and Deborah Zimmerman, MD, MScAinslie Hildebrand, MD, MScUniversity of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada (A.H.)Search for more papers by this author, Christine Ribic, MD, MScMcMaster University, Hamilton, Ontario, Canada (C.R.)Search for more papers by this author, and Deborah Zimmerman, MD, MScUniversity of Ottawa, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada (D.Z.)Search for more papers by this authorAuthor, Article, and Disclosure Informationhttps://doi.org/10.7326/M19-1504 SectionsAboutFull TextPDF ToolsAdd to favoritesDownload CitationsTrack CitationsPermissions ShareFacebookTwitterLinkedInRedditEmail The risks for venous thromboembolism (VTE) and atrial fibrillation (AF) are 2 to 3 times and 10 to 20 times greater in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and end-stage kidney disease (ESKD), respectively, than in the general population (1, 2). In patients with ESKD, VTE is associated with an increased risk for death and AF is associated with increased risks for stroke and death (1, 2).
